source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: The most important observation from this work has been the marked ameliorating effect that quite small additions of boron had on the corrosion rates of Zircaloy-4 in concentrated lithium-bearing environments

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: The presence of as little as $5 0 \mathrm { p p m }$ of boron, which is only one twentieth of the amount added to coolant at the start of a PWR operating cycle, has been shown to dramatically reduce corrosion rates in an environment containing $2 2 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ of lithium.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: Comparison of lithium pickup by the oxide in the lithium-only and lithiated and borated tests (Table 1) showed that the quantity of lithium which became incorporated in the scale was less in the presence of boron and, in general, decreased as the boron concentration in the bulk solution increased.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: In each case, the measured lithium concentration was below the McDonald et al. [5] threshold of $1 0 0 \mathrm { p p m }$ , despite the fact that a large rate increase was evident after only 84 days in the test without boron.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: The observation of accelerated corrosion rates in the test with $1 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ of boron, where rates were greater than when no boron was present, are of concern.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: In the tests reported here with $2 2 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ of lithium, the threshold boron concentration must lie between 10 and $5 0 \mathrm { p p m }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: In environments with a high lithium concentration $( 2 2 0 \ \mathsf { p p m } )$ to simulate hideout, boron additions from 50 to $8 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { p p m }$ resulted in a marked reduction in corrosion rate compared to tests without boron.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: Analysis of the oxides after $\sim 1 0 0$ days in four of these environments has indicated that this is a result of reduced lithium incorporation into the oxides in the presence of boron.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: the addition of $1 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$ of boron to a concentrated lithium solution resulted in consistently greater corrosion rates and more variability between repeat tests.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: Corrosion testing under isothermal conditions for short periods does not give an indication of the final post-transition corrosion rate because of a subsequent rate increase after longer exposure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_040_chunk5
evidence_span: Pre-oxidation of Zircaloy-4 in steam does not allow reliable prediction of long term corrosion rates.

evidence_span: the final oxide was so thin (1 to $1 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ )
